#PorterRobinson #Nurture #PianoMashup
Porter Robinson - The Nurture Piano Mashup (15 songs) | by keudae
48,335 viewsPremiered Jan 1, 2022
3.3K
DISLIKE
SHARE
DOWNLOAD
CLIP
SAVE
keudae
75K subscribers
SUBSCRIBED
I have never gotten to know a set of songs so well as the songs off of "Nurture." I truly hear every lyric in my head, and feel the weight of the notes as if I am singing through my fingers. I feared I wouldn't be able to finish this mashup before the new year but the transitions, the order in which to play them, and which keys to pick came easily since I had practiced every one of these songs for so many hours already. I put my heart and soul into not only this 15 (16 😬) song mashup but into every individual song itself over the past almost two years, and I'm grateful to all of you who have been on this journey with me 🤍🎹✨

Thank you @Porter Robinson for sharing your music with the world 🤍

★ “nurture piano mashup“ sheet music » https://www.musicnotes.com/l/Sc3MF

★ Patreon/Discord » https://bit.ly/2YrlGdO

I feared I wouldn't be able to finish this mashup before the new year but the transitions, the order in which to play them, and which keys to pick came easily since I had practiced every one of these songs for so many hours already. I put my heart and soul into not only this 15 (16 😬) song mashup but into every individual song itself over the past almost two years, and I'm grateful to all of you who have been on this journey with me 🤍🎹✨

Thank you @Porter Robinson for sharing your music with the world 🤍

Tab_Title: Porter Robinson, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs - Unfold | piano cover by keudae - YouTube
Tab_BodyText:
JP
SKIP NAVIGATION
0:00 / 10:33
#NF #NFRealMusic #CLOUDSTheMixtape
NF - CLOUDS (THE MIXTAPE) FULL PIANO MEDLEY | keudae
7,538 viewsPremiered Apr 26, 2021
597
DISLIKE
SHARE
DOWNLOAD
CLIP
SAVE
keudae
75K subscribers
SUBSCRIBED
Sometimes I need something that goes harder than John Mayer and Porter Robinson and that's when I turn to NF. My favorite rapper, ever. The only rapper who can make me bawl my eyes out.

I've broken down every song into essentially two parts: one quiet (verse) and one loud (chorus) piece based on the orchestral and piano backtrack because you can't specifically play rap on piano, you need pitches. It's more for if you want to be able to play along to the whole song, all you need is these two parts to repeat :) Sheet music coming soon.

★ Full medley sheet music » https://www.musicnotes.com/l/jHDZw
★ MIDI/chords/mp3 » https://bit.ly/2YrlGdO

Check out my piano medley for "The Search"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Z2Xd...

Sometimes I need something that goes harder than John Mayer and Porter Robinson and that's when I turn to NF. My favorite rapper, ever. The only rapper who can make me bawl my eyes out.

I've broken down every song into essentially two parts: one quiet (verse) and one loud (chorus) piece based on the orchestral and piano backtrack because you can't specifically play rap on piano, you need pitches. It's more for if you want to be able to play along to the whole song, all you need is these two parts to repeat :) Sheet music coming soon.

JP

#PorterRobinson #GoodbyetoaWorld #Worlds
Porter Robinson - Goodbye to a World | piano cover by keudae
70,454 viewsPremiered Jan 1, 2021
4.1K
DISLIKE
SHARE
DOWNLOAD
CLIP
SAVE
keudae
75K subscribers
SUBSCRIBED
I couldn't think of a better Porter song to end the year. Plus, wearing Madeon's merch so it's the two artists that influenced and inspired me the most in 2020 combined. 

Thank you to everyone who watched, liked, commented, subscribed, this year. And I'm especially grateful to my patrons, who give me more hope than I realized was out there to find. I'm excited for all the music I'll cover, arrange, play and teach next year :)

Page1/2
Page 1 of 2

Task description

Peer Learning with Programing

We are studying how data can be transferred from peer to peer. In this experiment, we will ask you to

solve programming tasks. The purpose of the experiment is to find a great digital source to share with

novice or fewer experienced programmers to support solving programming questions. To do so we

want to use a Google Chrome Extension called: TrackThinkVSCode, which is a search and coding

behavior logger. We will use this data to see how programmers solve a certain task.

We will present 3 results of text mining in a text and ask you to reproduce these results. You are going

to do it in the R language. The text mining is going to be done on a script it will be given to you in a

drawdown.txt. From this corpus, we ask you to create different wordcloud in the R language.

To code in R language, we recommend installing VSCode.

To do that please follow this link: https://code.visualstudio.com/download .

Please choose the free option and the version of your OS.

To code in R in VS code you have to add an extension. To do so, on the left side menu on VS code,

click on the extension icon and add the extension called R. To run your code on VS code click on the

arrow in the right upper corner.

Many solutions can be possible to recreate the results. We’ll ask you to finish the exercises. We want to

study how you did your research, so we want to see the process of your thinking and see all your trials.

Therefore, when you want to modify a line of code please leave the line you want to change and add

the modified line below.

To start the experiment you need to install the google extension called ThinkTrack, to do so, please

follow the instructions from this link: TrackThink | Manual. Please be sure to start logging after you

install the app and stop logging in after finishing the experiment. To do so, please click on the extension

button on the top right of your computer, then click on the three dots next to ThinkTrack and finally to

the management of the extension, then disable the extension. If you have a problem with that part, feel

free to ask us for some help.

Before going further to the answer questions, please answer this pre-survey.

https://forms.gle/uMuNmgdRRD9xzmcC9

Page 2 of 2

Write your code to solve these questions

1. From this corpus create the wordcloud like the example below :

2. Create a wordcloud from the corpus without the worlds:

can, energy, carbon, percent, emissions, one, will, word, water

3. Create a wordcloud from this corpus in a star shape.

Once you finish coding please answer this post-survey.

https://forms.gle/tT2QtHk1J13kJPSy8

Word Clouds in R: Useful & Beautiful Word Clouds with wordcloud2

In this video, I show you how to make word clouds with the tm library and wordcloud2 library in just a few minutes. We first start by cleaning our text, then building our word cloud. We don't just stop there though, because there are lots of potential improvements you can make to your wordcloud.

Code: https://github.com/abhimotgi/dataslic...
Kaggle Medium Posts Dataset: https://www.kaggle.com/dorianlazar/me...
Word Cloud 2 Documentation: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packag...
Marti Hearst's Medium Article: https://medium.com/multiple-views-vis...

0:00 Intro & Setup
1:44 Create corpus and clean text
3:44 Create term document matrix
5:14 Build word cloud
6:14 Improve your word cloud
12:09 Outro

Arguments of the word cloud generator function :
words : the words to be plotted.
freq : their frequencies.
min. freq : words with frequency below min. ...
max. words : maximum number of words to be plotted.
random. order : plot words in random order. ...
rot. ...
colors : color words from least to most frequent.

One can create a word cloud, also referred as text cloud or tag cloud, which is a visual representation of text data.Text miningword cloudtext cloudtag cloudThe procedure of creating word clouds is very simple in R if you know the different steps to execute. The text mining package (tm) and the word cloud generator package (wordcloud) are available in R for helping us to analyze texts and to quickly visualize the keywords as a word cloud.tmwordcloudIn this article, we’ll describe, step by step, how to generate word clouds using the R software.In this article, we’ll describe, step by step, how to generate word clouds using the R software.word clouds

 Text mining and word cloud fundamentals in R : 5 simple steps you should know
Tools

Text mining methods allow us to highlight the most frequently used keywords in a paragraph of texts. One can create a word cloud, also referred as text cloud or tag cloud, which is a visual representation of text data.

The procedure of creating word clouds is very simple in R if you know the different steps to execute. The text mining package (tm) and the word cloud generator package (wordcloud) are available in R for helping us to analyze texts and to quickly visualize the keywords as a word cloud.

In this article, we’ll describe, step by step, how to generate word clouds using the R software.



Contents
3 reasons you should use word clouds to present your text data
Who is using word clouds ?
The 5 main steps to create word clouds in R
Step 1: Create a text file
Step 2 : Install and load the required packages
Step 3 : Text mining
Step 4 : Build a term-document matrix
Step 5 : Generate the Word cloud
Go further
Explore frequent terms and their associations
The frequency table of words
Plot word frequencies
Infos




3 reasons you should use word clouds to present your text data
Word clouds add simplicity and clarity. The most used keywords stand out better in a word cloud
Word clouds are a potent communication tool. They are easy to understand, to be shared and are impactful
Word clouds are visually engaging than a table data
Who is using word clouds ?
Researchers : for reporting qualitative data
Marketers : for highlighting the needs and pain points of customers
Educators : to support essential issues
Politicians and journalists
social media sites : to collect, analyze and share user sentiments
The 5 main steps to create word clouds in R
Step 1: Create a text file

In the following examples, I’ll process the “I have a dream speech” from “Martin Luther King” but you can use any text you want :

Copy and paste the text in a plain text file (e.g : ml.txt)
Save the file

Note that, the text should be saved in a plain text (.txt) file format using your favorite text editor.

Step 2 : Install and load the required packages

Type the R code below, to install and load the required packages:

# Install
install.packages("tm")  # for text mining
install.packages("SnowballC") # for text stemming
install.packages("wordcloud") # word-cloud generator 
install.packages("RColorBrewer") # color palettes
# Load
library("tm")
library("SnowballC")
library("wordcloud")
library("RColorBrewer")
Step 3 : Text mining
load the text

The text is loaded using Corpus() function from text mining (tm) package. Corpus is a list of a document (in our case, we only have one document).

We start by importing the text file created in Step 1

To import the file saved locally in your computer, type the following R code. You will be asked to choose the text file interactively.

text <- readLines(file.choose())

In the example below, I’ll load a .txt file hosted on STHDA website:

# Read the text file from internet
filePath <- "http://www.sthda.com/sthda/RDoc/example-files/martin-luther-king-i-have-a-dream-speech.txt"
text <- readLines(filePath)
Load the data as a corpus
# Load the data as a corpus
docs <- Corpus(VectorSource(text))

VectorSource() function creates a corpus of character vectors

Inspect the content of the document
inspect(docs)
Text transformation

Transformation is performed using tm_map() function to replace, for example, special characters from the text.

Replacing “/”, “@” and “|” with space:

toSpace <- content_transformer(function (x , pattern ) gsub(pattern, " ", x))
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "/")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "@")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "\\|")
Cleaning the text

the tm_map() function is used to remove unnecessary white space, to convert the text to lower case, to remove common stopwords like ‘the’, “we”.

The information value of ‘stopwords’ is near zero due to the fact that they are so common in a language. Removing this kind of words is useful before further analyses. For ‘stopwords’, supported languages are danish, dutch, english, finnish, french, german, hungarian, italian, norwegian, portuguese, russian, spanish and swedish. Language names are case sensitive.

I’ll also show you how to make your own list of stopwords to remove from the text.

You could also remove numbers and punctuation with removeNumbers and removePunctuation arguments.

Another important preprocessing step is to make a text stemming which reduces words to their root form. In other words, this process removes suffixes from words to make it simple and to get the common origin. For example, a stemming process reduces the words “moving”, “moved” and “movement” to the root word, “move”.

Note that, text stemming require the package ‘SnowballC’.

The R code below can be used to clean your text :

# Convert the text to lower case
docs <- tm_map(docs, content_transformer(tolower))
# Remove numbers
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeNumbers)
# Remove english common stopwords
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, stopwords("english"))
# Remove your own stop word
# specify your stopwords as a character vector
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, c("blabla1", "blabla2")) 
# Remove punctuations
docs <- tm_map(docs, removePunctuation)
# Eliminate extra white spaces
docs <- tm_map(docs, stripWhitespace)
# Text stemming
# docs <- tm_map(docs, stemDocument)
Step 4 : Build a term-document matrix

Document matrix is a table containing the frequency of the words. Column names are words and row names are documents. The function TermDocumentMatrix() from text mining package can be used as follow :

dtm <- TermDocumentMatrix(docs)
m <- as.matrix(dtm)
v <- sort(rowSums(m),decreasing=TRUE)
d <- data.frame(word = names(v),freq=v)
head(d, 10)
             word freq
will         will   17
freedom   freedom   13
ring         ring   12
day           day   11
dream       dream   11
let           let   11
every       every    9
able         able    8
one           one    8
together together    7
Step 5 : Generate the Word cloud

The importance of words can be illustrated as a word cloud as follow :

set.seed(1234)
wordcloud(words = d$word, freq = d$freq, min.freq = 1,
          max.words=200, random.order=FALSE, rot.per=0.35, 
          colors=brewer.pal(8, "Dark2"))

The above word cloud clearly shows that “Will”, “freedom”, “dream”, “day” and “together” are the five most important words in the “I have a dream speech” from Martin Luther King.

Arguments of the word cloud generator function :



words : the words to be plotted
freq : their frequencies
min.freq : words with frequency below min.freq will not be plotted
max.words : maximum number of words to be plotted
random.order : plot words in random order. If false, they will be plotted in decreasing frequency
rot.per : proportion words with 90 degree rotation (vertical text)
colors : color words from least to most frequent. Use, for example, colors =“black” for single color.




Go further
Explore frequent terms and their associations

You can have a look at the frequent terms in the term-document matrix as follow. In the example below we want to find words that occur at least four times :

findFreqTerms(dtm, lowfreq = 4)
 [1] "able"     "day"      "dream"    "every"    "faith"    "free"     "freedom"  "let"      "mountain" "nation"  
[11] "one"      "ring"     "shall"    "together" "will"    

You can analyze the association between frequent terms (i.e., terms which correlate) using findAssocs() function. The R code below identifies which words are associated with “freedom” in I have a dream speech :

findAssocs(dtm, terms = "freedom", corlimit = 0.3)
$freedom
         let         ring  mississippi mountainside        stone        every     mountain        state 
        0.89         0.86         0.34         0.34         0.34         0.32         0.32         0.32 
The frequency table of words
head(d, 10)
             word freq
will         will   17
freedom   freedom   13
ring         ring   12
day           day   11
dream       dream   11
let           let   11
every       every    9
able         able    8
one           one    8
together together    7
Plot word frequencies

The frequency of the first 10 frequent words are plotted :

barplot(d[1:10,]$freq, las = 2, names.arg = d[1:10,]$word,
        col ="lightblue", main ="Most frequent words",
        ylab = "Word frequencies")
Infos

This analysis has been performed using R (ver. 3.3.2).

3 reasons you should use word clouds to present your text data
Word clouds add simplicity and clarity. The most used keywords stand out better in a word cloud
Word clouds are a potent communication tool. They are easy to understand, to be shared and are impactful
Word clouds are visually engaging than a table data3 reasons you should use word clouds to present your text dataWord clouds add simplicity and clarity. The most used keywords stand out better in a word cloud

The 5 main steps to create word clouds in RStep 1: Create a text file

In the following examples, I’ll process the “I have a dream speech” from “Martin Luther King” but you can use any text you want :

Copy and paste the text in a plain text file (e.g : ml.txt)
Save the file

Note that, the text should be saved in a plain text (.txt) file format using your favorite text editor.Step 1: Create a text fileIn the following examples, I’ll process the “I have a dream speech” from “Martin Luther King” but you can use any text you want :I have a dream speechMartin Luther KingCopy and paste the text in a plain text file (e.g : ml.txt)
Save the fileCopy and paste the text in a plain text file (e.g : ml.txt)Save the fileNote that, the text should be saved in a plain text (.txt) file format using your favorite text editor.Note that, the text should be saved in a plain text (.txt) file format using your favorite text editor.Step 2 : Install and load the required packages

Type the R code below, to install and load the required packages:

# Install
install.packages("tm")  # for text mining
install.packages("SnowballC") # for text stemming
install.packages("wordcloud") # word-cloud generator 
install.packages("RColorBrewer") # color palettes
# Load
library("tm")
library("SnowballC")
library("wordcloud")
library("RColorBrewer")Step 2 : Install and load the required packagesType the R code below, to install and load the required packages:# Install
install.packages("tm")  # for text mining
install.packages("SnowballC") # for text stemming
install.packages("wordcloud") # word-cloud generator 
install.packages("RColorBrewer") # color palettes
# Load
library("tm")
library("SnowballC")
library("wordcloud")
library("RColorBrewer")# Install
install.packages("tm")  # for text mining
install.packages("SnowballC") # for text stemming
install.packages("wordcloud") # word-cloud generator 
install.packages("RColorBrewer") # color palettes
# Load
library("tm")
library("SnowballC")
library("wordcloud")
library("RColorBrewer")# Installinstall.packages("tm")# for text mininginstall.packages("SnowballC")# for text stemminginstall.packages("wordcloud")# word-cloud generator install.packages("RColorBrewer")# color palettes# Loadlibrary("tm")library("SnowballC")library("wordcloud")library("RColorBrewer")Step 3 : Text mining

 R-Bloggers Datanovia: Online Data Science Courses Datanovia: Online Data Science Courses R-Bloggers R-BloggersStep 3 : Text miningload the text

The text is loaded using Corpus() function from text mining (tm) package. Corpus is a list of a document (in our case, we only have one document).

We start by importing the text file created in Step 1

To import the file saved locally in your computer, type the following R code. You will be asked to choose the text file interactively.

text <- readLines(file.choose())

In the example below, I’ll load a .txt file hosted on STHDA website:

# Read the text file from internet
filePath <- "http://www.sthda.com/sthda/RDoc/example-files/martin-luther-king-i-have-a-dream-speech.txt"
text <- readLines(filePath)
Load the data as a corpus
# Load the data as a corpus
docs <- Corpus(VectorSource(text))

VectorSource() function creates a corpus of character vectors

Inspect the content of the document
inspect(docs)load the textThe text is loaded using Corpus() function from text mining (tm) package. Corpus is a list of a document (in our case, we only have one document).Corpus()text miningWe start by importing the text file created in Step 1We start by importing the text file created in Step 1We start by importing the text file created in Step 1To import the file saved locally in your computer, type the following R code. You will be asked to choose the text file interactively.text <- readLines(file.choose())text <- readLines(file.choose())text<-readLines(file.choose())In the example below, I’ll load a .txt file hosted on STHDA website:# Read the text file from internet

text <- readLines(filePath)# Read the text file from internet

text <- readLines(filePath)# Read the text file from internetfilePath<-"http://www.sthda.com/sthda/RDoc/example-files/martin-luther-king-i-have-a-dream-speech.txt"text<-readLines(filePath)Load the data as a corpusLoad the data as a corpusLoad the data as a corpus# Load the data as a corpus
docs <- Corpus(VectorSource(text))# Load the data as a corpus
docs <- Corpus(VectorSource(text))# Load the data as a corpusdocs<-Corpus(VectorSource(text))VectorSource() function creates a corpus of character vectorsVectorSource() function creates a corpus of character vectors

The text is loaded using Corpus() function from text mining (tm) package. Corpus is a list of a document (in our case, we only have one document).

We start by importing the text file created in Step 1

To import the file saved locally in your computer, type the following R code. You will be asked to choose the text file interactively.

text <- readLines(file.choose())

In the example below, I’ll load a .txt file hosted on STHDA website:

# Read the text file from internet
filePath <- "http://www.sthda.com/sthda/RDoc/example-files/martin-luther-king-i-have-a-dream-speech.txt"
text <- readLines(filePath)
Load the data as a corpus
# Load the data as a corpus
docs <- Corpus(VectorSource(text))

VectorSource() function creates a corpus of character vectors

Inspect the content of the document

Text transformation

Transformation is performed using tm_map() function to replace, for example, special characters from the text.

Replacing “/”, “@” and “|” with space:

toSpace <- content_transformer(function (x , pattern ) gsub(pattern, " ", x))
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "/")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "@")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "\\|")Replacing “/”, “@” and “|” with space:toSpace <- content_transformer(function (x , pattern ) gsub(pattern, " ", x))
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "/")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "@")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "\\|")toSpace <- content_transformer(function (x , pattern ) gsub(pattern, " ", x))
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "/")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "@")
docs <- tm_map(docs, toSpace, "\\|")toSpace<-content_transformer(function(xpattern)gsub(pattern" "x))docs<-tm_map(docstoSpace"/")docs<-tm_map(docstoSpace"@")docs<-tm_map(docstoSpace"\\|")Cleaning the text

the tm_map() function is used to remove unnecessary white space, to convert the text to lower case, to remove common stopwords like ‘the’, “we”.

The information value of ‘stopwords’ is near zero due to the fact that they are so common in a language. Removing this kind of words is useful before further analyses. For ‘stopwords’, supported languages are danish, dutch, english, finnish, french, german, hungarian, italian, norwegian, portuguese, russian, spanish and swedish. Language names are case sensitive.

I’ll also show you how to make your own list of stopwords to remove from the text.

You could also remove numbers and punctuation with removeNumbers and removePunctuation arguments.

Another important preprocessing step is to make a text stemming which reduces words to their root form. In other words, this process removes suffixes from words to make it simple and to get the common origin. For example, a stemming process reduces the words “moving”, “moved” and “movement” to the root word, “move”.

Note that, text stemming require the package ‘SnowballC’.

The R code below can be used to clean your text :

# Convert the text to lower case
docs <- tm_map(docs, content_transformer(tolower))
# Remove numbers
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeNumbers)
# Remove english common stopwords
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, stopwords("english"))
# Remove your own stop word
# specify your stopwords as a character vector
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, c("blabla1", "blabla2")) 
# Remove punctuations
docs <- tm_map(docs, removePunctuation)
# Eliminate extra white spaces
docs <- tm_map(docs, stripWhitespace)
# Text stemming
# docs <- tm_map(docs, stemDocument)Cleaning the textthe tm_map() function is used to remove unnecessary white space, to convert the text to lower case, to remove common stopwords like ‘the’, “we”.tm_map()The information value of ‘stopwords’ is near zero due to the fact that they are so common in a language. Removing this kind of words is useful before further analyses. For ‘stopwords’, supported languages are danish, dutch, english, finnish, french, german, hungarian, italian, norwegian, portuguese, russian, spanish and swedish. Language names are case sensitive.I’ll also show you how to make your own list of stopwords to remove from the text.I’ll also show you how to make your own list of stopwords to remove from the text.You could also remove numbers and punctuation with removeNumbers and removePunctuation arguments.removeNumbersremovePunctuationAnother important preprocessing step is to make a text stemming which reduces words to their root form. In other words, this process removes suffixes from words to make it simple and to get the common origin. For example, a stemming process reduces the words “moving”, “moved” and “movement” to the root word, “move”.text stemmingNote that, text stemming require the package ‘SnowballC’.Note that, text stemming require the package ‘SnowballC’.The R code below can be used to clean your text :# Convert the text to lower casedocs<-tm_map(docscontent_transformer(tolower))# Remove numbersdocs<-tm_map(docsremoveNumbers)# Remove english common stopwords

Document matrix is a table containing the frequency of the words. Column names are words and row names are documents. The function TermDocumentMatrix() from text mining package can be used as follow :

dtm <- TermDocumentMatrix(docs)
m <- as.matrix(dtm)
v <- sort(rowSums(m),decreasing=TRUE)
d <- data.frame(word = names(v),freq=v)
head(d, 10)
             word freq
will         will   17
freedom   freedom   13
ring         ring   12
day           day   11
dream       dream   11
let           let   11
every       every    9
able         able    8
one           one    8
together together    7Step 4 : Build a term-document matrixDocument matrix is a table containing the frequency of the words. Column names are words and row names are documents. The function TermDocumentMatrix() from text mining package can be used as follow :TermDocumentMatrix()text miningdtm <- TermDocumentMatrix(docs)

v <- sort(rowSums(m),decreasing=TRUE)
d <- data.frame(word = names(v),freq=v)

# Convert the text to lower case
docs <- tm_map(docs, content_transformer(tolower))
# Remove numbers
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeNumbers)
# Remove english common stopwords
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, stopwords("english"))
# Remove your own stop word
# specify your stopwords as a character vector
docs <- tm_map(docs, removeWords, c("blabla1", "blabla2")) 
# Remove punctuations
docs <- tm_map(docs, removePunctuation)
# Eliminate extra white spaces
docs <- tm_map(docs, stripWhitespace)
# Text stemming
# docs <- tm_map(docs, stemDocument)# Convert the text to lower case

Step 4 : Build a term-document matrix

Document matrix is a table containing the frequency of the words. Column names are words and row names are documents. The function TermDocumentMatrix() from text mining package can be used as follow :

v <- sort(rowSums(m),decreasing=TRUE)
d <- data.frame(word = names(v),freq=v)

Scroll_VisibleText:
Step 5 : Generate the Word cloud

The importance of words can be illustrated as a word cloud as follow :

set.seed(1234)
wordcloud(words = d$word, freq = d$freq, min.freq = 1,
          max.words=200, random.order=FALSE, rot.per=0.35, 
          colors=brewer.pal(8, "Dark2"))

The above word cloud clearly shows that “Will”, “freedom”, “dream”, “day” and “together” are the five most important words in the “I have a dream speech” from Martin Luther King.

Arguments of the word cloud generator function :



words : the words to be plotted
freq : their frequencies
min.freq : words with frequency below min.freq will not be plotted
max.words : maximum number of words to be plotted
random.order : plot words in random order. If false, they will be plotted in decreasing frequency
rot.per : proportion words with 90 degree rotation (vertical text)
colors : color words from least to most frequent. Use, for example, colors =“black” for single color.

The above word cloud clearly shows that “Will”, “freedom”, “dream”, “day” and “together” are the five most important words in the “I have a dream speech” from Martin Luther King.

Arguments of the word cloud generator function :



words : the words to be plotted
freq : their frequencies
min.freq : words with frequency below min.freq will not be plotted
max.words : maximum number of words to be plotted
random.order : plot words in random order. If false, they will be plotted in decreasing frequency
rot.per : proportion words with 90 degree rotation (vertical text)
colors : color words from least to most frequent. Use, for example, colors =“black” for single color.

Go furtherExplore frequent terms and their associations

You can have a look at the frequent terms in the term-document matrix as follow. In the example below we want to find words that occur at least four times :

findFreqTerms(dtm, lowfreq = 4)
 [1] "able"     "day"      "dream"    "every"    "faith"    "free"     "freedom"  "let"      "mountain" "nation"  
[11] "one"      "ring"     "shall"    "together" "will"    

You can analyze the association between frequent terms (i.e., terms which correlate) using findAssocs() function. The R code below identifies which words are associated with “freedom” in I have a dream speech :

findAssocs(dtm, terms = "freedom", corlimit = 0.3)
$freedom
         let         ring  mississippi mountainside        stone        every     mountain        state 
        0.89         0.86         0.34         0.34         0.34         0.32         0.32         0.32 Explore frequent terms and their associationsYou can have a look at the frequent terms in the term-document matrix as follow. [11] "one"      "ring"     "shall"    "together" "will"     [1] "able"     "day"      "dream"    "every"    "faith"    "free"     "freedom"  "let"      "mountain" "nation"  
[11] "one"      "ring"     "shall"    "together" "will"    You can analyze the association between frequent terms (i.e., terms which correlate) using findAssocs() function. I couldn't think of a better Porter song to end the year. Plus, wearing Madeon's merch so it's the two artists that influenced and inspired me the most in 2020 combined. 

Thank you to everyone who watched, liked, commented, subscribed, this year. And I'm especially grateful to my patrons, who give me more hope than I realized was out there to find. I'm excited for all the music I'll cover, arrange, play and teach next year :)

Tab_Title: Porter Robinson - Goodbye to a World | piano cover by keudae - YouTube
Tab_BodyText:
JP
SKIP NAVIGATION
0:00 / 6:29
#PorterRobinson #Nurture
Porter Robinson - dullscythe | keudae *FINAL BOSS* piano cover
34,805 viewsPremiered Sep 13, 2021
2.7K
DISLIKE
SHARE
DOWNLOAD
CLIP
SAVE
keudae
75K subscribers
SUBSCRIBED
I shortened some riffs, I lengthened some riffs so it was easier on the ears with a more common time signature (rather than none at all haha). I created transitions, added a couple chords, mixed in 4 other Porter songs, raised the key so it was "out of tune" like the original (in-between Dm and Ebm) and the whole practicing and arranging process was honestly... bittersweet. The final of 15 piano covers to complete the Nurture album. From "Something Comforting" in March of 2020, to "dullscythe" in September 2021. I definitely have Porter and Nurture to thank for my channel, Patreon, and sheet music job doing as well as it is. And, for all the kind, genuine friends and patrons I've made online along the way. Thank you guys.

That's NOT to say I'll never play something off Nurture (or Worlds wink*) ever again! I'm excited for the new songs and new artists we'll listen to and cover this fall 🤍

Nurture, the piano cover album will be coming to Spotify/Apple Music soon, I'm excited! 🥳 I'm also relieved I was able to finish this A WEEK BEFORE SECOND SKY 😅🌸

★ “dullscythe“ sheet music » https://www.musicnotes.com/l/cxKM4

★ Patreon/Discord » https://bit.ly/2YrlGdO 
★ Sheet Music » https://bit.ly/2YXDMTS 
★ Instagram » https://bit.ly/2Vj2QUp

🌱 Nurture piano covers YouTube playlist »
https://bit.ly/3994DC2

“Wind Tempos” https://youtu.be/GTE7hMOTcQ4
“Musician” https://youtu.be/QWJiQeAtouc
“do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti-do” https://youtu.be/Wsvs713NuNM

Tab_BodyText:
JP

0:00 / 4:39
#Shelter #PorterRobinson #Madeon
Porter Robinson & Madeon - Shelter | keudae piano cover
38,481 viewsPremiered Oct 29, 2020
2.3K
DISLIKE
SHARE
DOWNLOAD
CLIP
SAVE
keudae
75K subscribers
SUBSCRIBED
Pleaaaaaase leave a like, comment and share if you like this video, it really supports my channel and helps with the YouTube algorithm :)

This is the piano version of the jazzified "Shelter" that's become my most popular video in years. Thank you for 100k views on it!! I wanted to share this more chill version, keeping the chords I used before. I hope you like it :)

I am currently looking for my own shelter, in cold Montana. I've been posting everything to my "montana autumn" instagram highlight if you wanna see some snow, mountains, lots of driving.

How to deal with error “undefined columns selected when subsetting data frame” in R?
R ProgrammingServer Side ProgrammingProgramming
R Programming Online Training

40 Lectures  1.5 hours

 Ashish Sharma

More Detail
Support Vector Machines In R (SVM In R)

27 Lectures  3 hours

 Abhishek And Pukhraj

More Detail
Data Visualization Using R Programming

14 Lectures  10 hours

 DATAhill Solutions Srinivas Reddy

More Detail

The error “undefined columns selected when subsetting data frame” means that R does not understand the column that you want to use while subsetting the data frame. Generally, this happens when we forget to use comma while subsetting with single square brackets.

Example

Consider the below data frame −

> set.seed(99)
> x1<-rnorm(20,0.5)
> x2<-rpois(20,2)
> x3<-runif(20,2,10)
> x4<-rnorm(20,0.2)
> x5<-rpois(20,5)
> df<-data.frame(x1,x2,x3,x4,x5)
> df
x1 x2 x3 x4 x5
1 0.7139625 4 9.321058 0.33297863 4
2 0.9796581 2 4.298837 -1.47926432 11
3 0.5878287 3 7.389898 -0.07847958 5
4 0.9438585 4 7.873764 -1.35241100 6
5 0.1371621 2 5.534758 -1.17969925 4
6 0.6226740 4 8.786676 -1.15705659 5
7 -0.3638452 1 6.407712 -0.72113718 5
8 0.9896243 2 9.374095 -0.66681774 9
9 0.1358831 2 2.086996 1.85664439 3
10 -0.7942420 0 8.730721 0.04492028 3
11 -0.2457690 3 2.687042 -1.37655243 2
12 1.4215504 3 7.075115 0.82408260 4
13 1.2500544 3 5.373809 0.53022068 5
14 -2.0085540 5 5.287499 -0.19812226 12
15 -2.5409341 1 6.217131 -0.88139693 5
16 0.5002658 3 2.723290 0.12307794 6
17 0.1059810 0 6.288451 -0.32553662 4
18 -1.2450277 2 2.942365 0.59128965 5
19 0.9986315 4 7.012492 -0.48045326 6
20 0.7709538 1 7.801093 -0.54869693 5

Now suppose, you want to select rows where x2 is greater than 2 and you type of the following code −

> df[df$x2>2]
Error in `[.data.frame`(df, df$x2 > 2) : undefined columns selected

It is throwing an error of undefined columns because you forgot the comma after defining your objective. The appropriate way to select the rows where x2 is greater than 2 is as shown below −

> df[df$x2>2,]
x1 x2 x3 x4 x5
1 0.7139625 4 9.321058 0.33297863 4
3 0.5878287 3 7.389898 -0.07847958 5
4 0.9438585 4 7.873764 -1.35241100 6
6 0.6226740 4 8.786676 -1.15705659 5
11 -0.2457690 3 2.687042 -1.37655243 2
12 1.4215504 3 7.075115 0.82408260 4
13 1.2500544 3 5.373809 0.53022068 5
14 -2.0085540 5 5.287499 -0.19812226 12
16 0.5002658 3 2.723290 0.12307794 6
19 0.9986315 4 7.012492 -0.48045326 6

Similarly, to select the rows where x2 is less than 2 is as follows −

> df[df$x2<2,]
x1 x2 x3 x4 x5
7 -0.3638452 1 6.407712 -0.72113718 5
10 -0.7942420 0 8.730721 0.04492028 3
15 -2.5409341 1 6.217131 -0.88139693 5
17 0.1059810 0 6.288451 -0.32553662 4
20 0.7709538 1 7.801093 -0.54869693 5

In the same way, the selection of rows where x2 is greater than 1 is as follows −

> df[df$x2>1,]
x1 x2 x3 x4 x5
1 0.7139625 4 9.321058 0.33297863 4
2 0.9796581 2 4.298837 -1.47926432 11
3 0.5878287 3 7.389898 -0.07847958 5
4 0.9438585 4 7.873764 -1.35241100 6
5 0.1371621 2 5.534758 -1.17969925 4
6 0.6226740 4 8.786676 -1.15705659 5
8 0.9896243 2 9.374095 -0.66681774 9
9 0.1358831 2 2.086996 1.85664439 3
11 -0.2457690 3 2.687042 -1.37655243 2
12 1.4215504 3 7.075115 0.82408260 4
13 1.2500544 3 5.373809 0.53022068 5
14 -2.0085540 5 5.287499 -0.19812226 12
16 0.5002658 3 2.723290 0.12307794 6
18 -1.2450277 2 2.942365 0.59128965 5
19 0.9986315 4 7.012492 -0.48045326 6

> x1<-rnorm(20,0.5)
> x2<-rpois(20,2)
> x3<-runif(20,2,10)
> x4<-rnorm(20,0.2)
> x5<-rpois(20,5)
> df<-data.frame(x1,x2,x3,x4,x5)
> df

20 0.7709538 1 7.801093 -0.54869693 5Now suppose, you want to select rows where x2 is greater than 2 and you type of the following code −> df[df$x2>2]
Error in `[.data.frame`(df, df$x2 > 2) : undefined columns selected> df[df$x2>2]
Error in `[.data.frame`(df, df$x2 > 2) : undefined columns selectedIt is throwing an error of undefined columns because you forgot the comma after defining your objective. The appropriate way to select the rows where x2 is greater than 2 is as shown below −> df[df$x2>2,]

Word Clouds in R: Useful & Beautiful Word Clouds with wordcloud2

In this video, I show you how to make word clouds with the tm library and wordcloud2 library in just a few minutes. We first start by cleaning our text, then building our word cloud. We don't just stop there though, because there are lots of potential improvements you can make to your wordcloud.

Code: https://github.com/abhimotgi/dataslic...
Kaggle Medium Posts Dataset: https://www.kaggle.com/dorianlazar/me...
Word Cloud 2 Documentation: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packag...
Marti Hearst's Medium Article: https://medium.com/multiple-views-vis...

0:00 Intro & Setup
1:44 Create corpus and clean text
3:44 Create term document matrix
5:14 Build word cloud
6:14 Improve your word cloud
12:09 Outro

Word Clouds in R: Useful & Beautiful Word Clouds with wordcloud2

In this video, I show you how to make word clouds with the tm library and wordcloud2 library in just a few minutes. We first start by cleaning our text, then building our word cloud. We don't just stop there though, because there are lots of potential improvements you can make to your wordcloud.

Code: https://github.com/abhimotgi/dataslic...
Kaggle Medium Posts Dataset: https://www.kaggle.com/dorianlazar/me...
Word Cloud 2 Documentation: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packag...
Marti Hearst's Medium Article: https://medium.com/multiple-views-vis...

0:00 Intro & Setup
1:44 Create corpus and clean text
3:44 Create term document matrix
5:14 Build word cloud
6:14 Improve your word cloud
12:09 Outro

Tab_Title: 02a wordcloud2 and lettercloud.txt - Google Drive
Tab_BodyText:
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Wordcloud2 for social media responses on COVID-19 pandemic

# step-by-step approach to word cloud generation

# step 1: load libraries NLP, tm, RColorBrewer, SnowballC, wordcloud, 
#         stringr, wordcloud2
# step 2: input text data file pandemic_30052020.csv
# step 3: clean the text data with tm and stringr functions
# step 4: make corpus and dtm (document-term-matrix)
# step 5: generate word cloud 

#---------------------------------------------------
# load the required packages
# input data data pandemic_30052020

library(NLP)
library(tm)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(SnowballC)
library(wordcloud)
library(stringr)
library(wordcloud2)

# read in pandemic_30052020.csv as input file
reviews <- read.csv(file.choose(), sep=",", header=T)

abc <- as.matrix(reviews)
head(abc)
tail(abc)

#---------------------------------------------------

#text data cleaning

# stringr functions for removing symbols
abc <- str_remove_all(abc,"–")
abc <- str_remove_all(abc,"’")
abc <- str_remove_all(abc,"—")
abc <- str_remove_all(abc,"“")
abc <- str_remove_all(abc,"”")

# tm functions for text cleaning
abc<-removeNumbers(abc)
abc<-removePunctuation(abc)
abc<-tolower(abc)
abc<-removeWords(abc,c("now", "one", "will", "may", "says", "said", 
                       "also", "figure", "etc", "re", "can"))
stopwords<-c("the", "and", stopwords("en"))
abc<-removeWords(abc, stopwords("en"))
abc<-stripWhitespace(abc)
abc<-wordStem(abc)        #function from SnowballC

reviews <- abc
head(reviews)
tail(reviews)

#---------------------------------------------------

#A vector source interprets each element of the vector as a document
review.source<-VectorSource(reviews)

#form corpus from vector source
corpus<-Corpus(review.source)
inspect(corpus[1:10])

#make document-term-matrix
dtm<-TermDocumentMatrix(corpus)
inspect(dtm[51:60,10:20])

dtm2<-as.matrix(dtm)
frequency <- sort(rowSums(dtm2), decreasing=T)
head(frequency)
words<-names(frequency)

#---------------------------------------------------

#Visualization of the data
plot(frequency, col="darkblue")

df<- data.frame(names(frequency), frequency)

#visualization via wordcloud package
wordcloud2(df, size=0.7, shape="star", widgetsize=c(1000,1000))
wordcloud2(df, size=0.7, shape="diamond", widgetsize=c(800,800))

#---------------------------------------------------


02a wordcloud2 and lettercloud.txt

Pleaaaaaase leave a like, comment and share if you like this video, it really supports my channel and helps with the YouTube algorithm :)

This is the piano version of the jazzified "Shelter" that's become my most popular video in years. Thank you for 100k views on it!! I wanted to share this more chill version, keeping the chords I used before. I hope you like it :)

I am currently looking for my own shelter, in cold Montana. I've been posting everything to my "montana autumn" instagram highlight if you wanna see some snow, mountains, lots of driving.

I played on my Korg Kross and recorded with Ableton Live.
Thank you for watching ♥

Holding this song close for strength because the time to be brave isn't "one day," it's not "soon," it's now.

★ "Look at the Sky" sheet music » https://www.musicnotes.com/l/3MfF8
★ "Look at the Sky" piano tutorial » https://youtu.be/sPlyFB763Xk

★ Behind the scenes practicing, my thoughts on arranging this song, and my reaction to watching the lyric video for the first time on January 27th (Patreon exclusive, now live) 

★ Patreon/Discord » https://bit.ly/2YrlGdO 
★ Sheet Music » https://bit.ly/2YXDMTS 
★ Instagram » https://bit.ly/2Vj2QUp

🌱 Nurture piano covers YouTube playlist »
https://bit.ly/3994DC2 

NURTURE COVERS COMPLETE
“Lifelike”  https://youtu.be/bnv2rMlV8Zk
“Look at the Sky” https://youtu.be/XkJouW-zoRs 
“Get Your Wish” https://youtu.be/JdJI53PhstA 
“Wind Tempos” https://youtu.be/GTE7hMOTcQ4
“Musician” https://youtu.be/QWJiQeAtouc
“do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti-do” https://youtu.be/Wsvs713NuNM 
“Mother” https://youtu.be/Zc9rVx3kH6s 
“dullscythe” https://youtu.be/4mF3qhbuIGI 
“Sweet Time” https://youtu.be/f6dGYzz3auE 
“Mirror” https://youtu.be/FgBShwyRqe8 
“Something Comforting” https://youtu.be/K_uRJvpgF5g
“Blossom” https://youtu.be/md6x5c6qXsM 
“Unfold” https://youtu.be/5qjU7Wo1P4U 
“Trying to Feel Alive” https://youtu.be/MSpTOJiGZFg 
“Fullmoon Lullaby” https://youtu.be/Yf-tsStRx8o

Listen on:
★ Spotify » https://spoti.fi/2FUbC6G 
★ Apple Music/iTunes » https://apple.co/3opCXip  
★ Amazon Music » https://amzn.to/38pHbAd  

I played on my @Korg Kross and recorded with @Ableton Live.
If you're like me, you've been waiting patiently for 9 long months for the full version of this song and finally, it's here to hold us over until Nurture 🔑

Thank you for watching 💙
